big_picture_notes: Joshua functions as the hinge between the promise of the Torah and the possession in the rest of the Old Testament. Its three-part structure (Conquest, Division, Covenant) masterfully balances epic narrative with geographical lists. The entire book is held together by the theme of fulfillment—God keeps His covenant promise to give the land. The book is profoundly Deuteronomistic: obedience leads to victory; disobedience leads to defeat. The phrase 'Be strong and courageous' links Joshua's leadership to Moses', while the deaths of Joshua and Eleazar formally close the conquest generation.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Starts with 'After the death of Moses' (1:1), a clear narrative starting point marking a new era and divine oracle. Ends with the complete list of defeated kings (12:24), a perfect colophon to the military campaign. Held together by yaraš (to possess/dispossess), the repeated fulfillment of herem (devotion to destruction), and Joshua as the new Moses.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with 'The LORD spoke to Joshua.' Ends with the divine promise 'the LORD your God is with you.' Unified by inclusio: 'Be strong and courageous' (vv. 6, 7, 9). Central importance of the 'Book of the Law.'
Starts with Joshua commanding the officers. Ends with the tribes' pledge of allegiance, echoing God's words ('be strong and courageous'). Shows Joshua's established authority.
Starts with 'Joshua sent spies.' Ends with 'the gate was shut,' a narrative cliffhanger. Introduces key characters and central tension through dialogue and deception.
Starts with 'Before they lay down' (rooftop scene). Ends with 'she sent them away,' the covenant finalized. Structured around Rahab's confession, plea, and oath-sealing with the scarlet cord.
Starts with 'And they went.' Ends with 'Truly the LORD has given all the land.' Contrasts with the faithless spies of Numbers 13; sets stage for conquest.
Starts with 'Joshua rose early.' Ends with 'Take up the ark.' Unified as final preparation for crossing. Central focus on the Ark and consecration command.
Starts with 'The LORD said to Joshua.' Ends with 'all Israelites had passed over on dry ground.' Structured as promise and fulfillment. Central image: parting of waters (parallel to Red Sea).
Starts with 'When all people had finished.' Ends with summary statement 'to exalt Joshua.' Unified by the single topic of the twelve stones with divine command and explanation.
Starts with 'The LORD said to Joshua.' Ends with 'fear the LORD your God forever.' Priests come up, river returns, Joshua provides theological explanation.
Single-verse hinge scene. Functions as result of Jordan miracle, summarizing its effect on Canaanites. Transitions from entry to consecration narrative.
Starts with 'At that time the LORD said.' Ends with etiological formula explaining 'Gilgal' (wordplay: galal/rolled). Unified as covenant renewal through circumcision.
Starts with 'While Israelites were encamped.' Ends with 'produce of the land.' Three-verse unit marking end of wilderness era and beginning of blessing in the land.

scenes.scene_name: The Captain of the LORD's Host
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with 'When Joshua was by Jericho.' Ends with 'Joshua did so.' Theophany parallel to Moses at burning bush. Reframes conflict: God's battle, not Israel's.

scenes.scene_name: The Divine Battle Plan for Jericho
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with parenthesis setting stage (6:1). Ends with 'the wall will fall down flat.' Single divine speech laying out the seemingly absurd, ritualistic plan.
Starts with 'Joshua called the priests.' Ends with 'Joshua said, Shout!' Details six-day ritual and seven circuits, building narrative tension through repetition.
Starts with 'The city... shall be... devoted.' Ends with 'So the LORD was with Joshua.' Climax and resolution including shout, fall, herem execution, and sparing of Rahab.

scenes.scene_name: Achan's Sin and the Defeat at Ai
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with 'But the Israelites... Achan.' Ends with 'I will be with you no more.' Moves from hidden sin to public defeat to God's revelation of the problem.
Starts with 'Go, consecrate the people.' Ends with 'Valley of Achor,' the place named after the judgment. Solemn ritualistic judgment building tension through lot-casting to the final man.
Starts with 'The LORD said to Joshua.' Ends with 'lodged that night.' Post-repentance divine oracle contrasting with human plan in chapter 7. Key element: ambush strategy.

scenes.scene_name: The Capture and Destruction of Ai
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with 'When king of Ai saw.' Ends with 'a great heap of stones to this day.' Full-scale battle narrative perfectly following the plan: feigned retreat, signal, ambush, herem, king's execution.

scenes.scene_name: The Covenant Renewal on Mount Ebal
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with 'Joshua built an altar.' Ends with 'conversant among them.' Narrative pause to fulfill Moses' command (Deut. 27). Solemn liturgical event around altar, law writing, and reading of blessings/curses.
Starts with 'As soon as all kings.' Ends with 'the princes swore.' Story of deception. Pivotal verse 14: 'did not ask counsel from the LORD,' contrasting with Joshua's faithfulness.
Starts with 'At the end of three days.' Ends with 'to this day,' Gibeonites' fate sealed. Consequences of previous deception: people's murmuring, princes' defense, curse pronounced.
Starts with 'Now Adoni-zedek.' Ends with 'they died' (hailstones). Covers Gibeonite plea, divine oracle, all-night march, and initial victory credited to God's hailstones.
Starts with 'At that time Joshua spoke.' Ends with 'returned to camp at Gilgal.' Theological and poetic heart of battle. Quotes poetic 'Book of Jashar.' Declares 'the LORD fought for Israel.'
Starts with 'These five kings fled.' Ends with 'utterly destroyed all.' Single event: capture and symbolic execution. Joshua's command to chiefs is symbolic act of complete domination.

Starts with 'Then Joshua... passed from Makkedah.' Ends with 'returned unto camp.' Not detailed narrative but 'conquest montage' using repetitive formula covering five cities (Libnah, Lachish, Eglon, Hebron, Debir).
Starts with 'When Jabin... heard.' Ends with 'as the LORD commanded Moses.' Parallel to southern campaign but condensed: enemy coalition, divine promise, battle, herem execution.

Starts with 'So Joshua took all that land.' Ends with 'the land had rest from war.' Perfect narrative conclusion to entire conquest. Explicitly links Joshua's actions to Moses' command. Sets stage for division story.

Starts with 'Now these are the kings.' Ends with 'all the kings thirty-one.' Formal appendix/colophon in two parts: kings east of Jordan (Moses' conquests), kings west of Jordan (Joshua's conquests). Provides 'receipts' for fulfillment.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Starts with 'Now Joshua was old' (13:1), a clear narrative shift from conquest to allotment. New divine command: divide this land. Ends with triumphant theological summary (21:45): 'There failed not aught of any good thing... all came to pass.' Chapter 22 begins new story. Held together by repetitive formulas ('The lot of the tribe of...') and the theme of nahala (inheritance). Entire section is 'Domesday Book' of Israel—theological geography.

scenes.scene_name: The Command to Divide the Land
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with 'Joshua was old.' Ends with 'divide this land.' Introduces entire second half. Lists land yet to be conquered and gives overarching command to allot all of it.

Starts with 'With whom the Reubenites.' Ends with 'the LORD... was their inheritance.' Unified geographical review recounting allotment for Reuben, Gad, half-Manasseh already made by Moses. Note about Levi frames section.
Starts with 'And these are the inheritances.' Ends with 'they divided the land.' Brief formal introduction naming agents (Eleazar, Joshua, heads of fathers) and establishing method (by lot).

Starts with 'Then children of Judah came.' Ends with 'the land had rest from war.' First narrative scene breaking up lists. Caleb's speech contrasts unfaithful spies with his wholehearted following of the LORD.
Starts with 'The lot of tribe of Judah.' Ends with 'border of children of Judah.' Pure boundary list scene. Geographically structured: south, east, north, west borders.
Starts with 'And unto Caleb.' Ends with 'springs of water.' Narrative embedded in Judah allotment. Details Caleb's conquest and Achsah's bold request for water springs.

Starts with 'This is the inheritance.' Ends with 'unto this day.' Long city list—single literary unit organized by region: Negeb, Shephelah, hill country, wilderness. Ends with note of incomplete conquest (Jebusites).

Starts with 'The lot of children of Joseph.' Ends with 'drive out the Canaanites.' Long but unified section on Joseph's sons (Ephraim, Manasseh). Includes Zelophehad's daughters special note and dialogue on Joseph's complaint.

scenes.scene_name: The Tabernacle at Shiloh and the Seven Tribes
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with 'whole congregation assembled at Shiloh.' Ends with 'Joshua divided the land.' Crucial narrative pivot. Tabernacle set up at land's center. Joshua rebukes seven tribes for delay, institutes land survey and lot-casting plan.
Starts with 'lot of tribe of Benjamin.' Ends with 'their inheritance.' Single unified allotment unit containing boundaries and city list.

scenes.scene_name: The Lots of Simeon through Dan
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with 'And second lot came forth.' Ends with 'their inheritance.' Covers six tribes (Simeon, Zebulun, Issachar, Asher, Naphtali, Dan) with same parallel formula structure.

Starts with 'When they had made an end.' Ends with 'made an end of dividing.' Brief but powerful conclusion to tribal allotments. Parallels Caleb's scene but shows Joshua's humility: waits until all serve first.
Starts with 'The LORD also spoke.' Ends with 'slain by the avenger.' Single unified legal section fulfilling Numbers 35 command. Details purpose and names the cities.

Starts with 'Then came heads of Levites.' Ends with 'its suburbs.' Final piece of allotment. Details request and fulfillment, then lists cities by Levitical family (Kohathites, Gershonites, Merarites).

Starts with 'And the LORD gave unto Israel.' Ends with 'all came to pass.' Theological climax and summation. Three-fold declaration of God's faithfulness: gave land, gave rest, not one promise failed.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Starts with 'Then Joshua called the Reubenites' (22:1), new narrative action logically following completion of war and allotment. Ends with 'Eleazar... died' (24:33), death of entire leadership generation (Joshua, Eleazar) mirroring book's start with Moses' death. Formally closes the conquest era. Held together by theme of covenant faithfulness, fear of apostasy, and repeated call to 'serve the LORD.'

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with 'Then Joshua called.' Ends with 'departed.' Single unified scene of dismissal containing commendation, final charge, blessing, and departure.

scenes.scene_name: The Altar of Witness and the Crisis
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with 'built there an altar.' Ends with 'perished not alone in his iniquity.' The crisis: altar misinterpreted. Phinehas's speech lays out accusation using precedents of Peor and Achan.
Starts with 'Then children of Reuben.' Ends with 'a witness between us.' Resolution scene. Transjordan tribes defend altar's purpose. Phinehas accepts, delegation returns, civil war averted.

Starts with 'A long time after.' Ends with 'perish quickly from off the good land.' Single complete Deuteronomistic farewell discourse. Contains: historical review, exhortation to obedience, solemn warning/curse.
Starts with 'Joshua gathered.' Ends with 'ye did not plant.' Historical prologue to covenant renewal. Joshua recites Israel's salvation history from Abraham through conquest as basis for covenant.

Starts with 'Now therefore fear the LORD.' Ends with 'unto his inheritance.' Covenant-making scene following classic treaty structure: call, decision ('choose this day'), pledge, stipulations, formal acceptance, witnessing.
Starts with 'After these things.' Ends with 'in a hill.' Formal epilogue recording three key deaths: Joshua, Joseph's bones buried, Eleazar dies. Entire founding generation at rest.
